ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Graeme Berlyn is an FES institution, and everyone should be required to take at least one of his classes. There was an excess of complex material, including a lot of subjects that I will likely never understand or need in my career, but it was great to have my eyes opened to their presence.
This course is very useful to my study field.The instructor is excellent.The TA is very helpful.
Graeme is wonderful. His knowledge is encyclopaedic, and he is happy to share his knowledge with students. I feel honored that I was able to take this class.

I loved the moments when Prof. Berlyn would grow passionate about something (such as the simultaneous decision of fusiform initials to create vessel elements all the way up and down the stem of a tree). I also loved his stories, gripes, and color commentary.More broadly, his ideas and teaching style are different from those of almost all other professors at FES, and this is what makes the class experience so valuable.
I can always explore my interest field in this course.This course provides lots of useful knowledge and at the same time makes me relax-it is not pushing at all, but very helpful.

Graeme is very knowledgeable and personable.Its good that the test questions were somewhat open ended. It would have been a nightmare to try to study all of the material, if expected to master every detail.

The best part was that the application was emphasized over simply repeating the information. The use of the knowledge gained in the class was more important than knowing one specific detail that may or may not be relevant to actually affecting change in the world.
Graeme's infinite stock of examples and stories. Graeme also takes questions seriously - he stops his lecture, thinks, and then gives a thoughtful response. I appreciate that.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The posted lecture notes are so jumbled and difficult to decipher that they become almost useless. If Prof. Berlyn does not want to take the time to sort it all out, this is understandable, but someone should take the initiative to do it with him.
A field trip to mountains or woods could be very helpful.

The lecture style of the course was not very engaging. The material is so detailed and "cell-level" that its hard to get the bigger picture. I did not find the lectures especially helpful when it came to preparing for the tests.

The slides go way too fast for note-taking. This is fine in the end, because not every detail is needed to be documented for the style of the final, but it would be nice for personal knowledge to be able to jot down more stuff.
more review sessions?

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both instructor and TA were approachable, knowledgeable, generous with their time, and helpful.
The instructor helps me with my term paper.The TA helps me with the exam preparation.
Martin was available to help and hosted several review sessions.

Very good TA, held effective review sessions, answered most questions thoroughly, and obviously spent much of his own time preparing extra material to aid us in studying for the midterm and the final.

Graeme was always available to help and talk to us after class, before class, or in his office.Martin was extremely helpful and put in a lot of time into organizing review sessions that were an excellent resource for exam preparation. You'll be a fantastic professor - you're very talented at making complex matters seem straightforward. Thank you!

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I'm learning how to become a forester, and the understanding of how trees function, as well as how they respond to their environment, is extremely important.
This course provides me some systematic knowledge of vascular plants, from anatomical to ecophysiological perspective, which is well-detailed and inspiring.
Its good to have the plant bio background, but this was more detailed info than I needed.
A necessary part of the forestry program. More people should take this course.
It's a basic requirement for working with trees.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course because Mark Ashton told me I should, and said that I would get a lot out of it.
It is a fundamental course for my major.
To gain a greater plant bio background as a foundation to other classes and my career.
I thought it was a staple of the forestry program, and it was.
I want to better understand how trees function.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: It exceeded my expectations, and I found that I enjoyed the material more than I ever thought I would have.
Yes, it did.
No. I'm sorry to say it.
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: The sheer quantity of knowledge I poured into my midterm and final exams shows me that I got much more out of it than I expected.
Yes.
Mostly.
Yes, and more.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantage:it is very helpful(especially for the exam preparation) to discuss the remained questions with the TA.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Type quickly, read the textbook, and don't expect to learn everything he throws at you. Do what you can, enjoy what you learn, and try to fit it all together into a larger context for the final.Write your paper on a subject that interests you, but also forces you to expand your knowledge.
Take notes carefully.Read Raven's book before you go to class.
Don't worry about taking notes, because the lectures go too fast. Just listen, do the readings and review later. Don't sweat the details, because the questions are general.
when you take notes, type what you hear, not what's on the slides. the slides are on ClassesV2, Graeme's stories and details are not.
